page.title: 16Club Day,Kingsbury.
page.content: There was a friendly society in Kingsbury until 1910.The men paid a shilling a week,the women sixpence. Members could have financial help in times of sickness.We talked to a lady, who told us how much she had looked forward as a child to the Club Day. First there was a church service for the members.Then they went to the Wyndham Arms in a procession headed by the band and a banner.The men's march was on Tuesday,the women's on Thursday.In a marquee the men had roast lunch and the women had tea. After lunch the men went around the farms.Then they went back to the fair by the Wyndham.There were swingboats, coconut shies and rides for a penny. Liquorice sticks,sherbert and dumps (striped sweets) were a penny each. There was a dance in the marquee in the evening.
